{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3569766,"name":"","username":"jacob_mazelin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jacob_mazelin/{size}/213574_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-27T02:41:18.098Z","cooked":"

Hello CD,

We’re running a Kraken MK4i swerve with PathPlanner and trying to dial in our translation PID. To test, we created a simple 5-meter straight path with 4 m/s max velocity and 4 m/s² acceleration. We’ve had success with 4m/s and 2.5m/s², but want to go a little bit faster.

The robot consistently ends about 6 inches short, even when repeating the run multiple times. We expected increasing the translation P gain would help, but:

  • At P = 3.0 → 6 inches short
  • At P = 10.0 → still 6 inches short
  • No oscillations or overcorrections, just undershoot.

Some details:

  • We’re using AutoBuilder with a PPHolonomicDriveController.
  • Trajectory completes without errors or abrupt motions.
  • Chassis speeds and odometry look normal during the path.

If translation P has no effect, where should we be looking?

  • Is it possible our odometry is off, and the PID is doing nothing?
  • Would adding a small I gain help even though this is just a 1D test?
  • Should we try changing the P on our Kraken drive gains instead? Maybe add a FF to the Kraken gains? Steer has all zero FF while drive only has kV at 0.124. No kS on either

Here is our code. I’d appreciate any insight!

I believe PathPlanner has a somewhat large tolerance for reaching the end of a path, at which point it stops the PID controller.

If you want to end at a precise position you should probably have a separate PID based command for driving the swerve to a target pose.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-27T02:50:05.449Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":497092,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-pid-tuning-translation-p-not-affecting-undershoot","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-pid-tuning-translation-p-not-affecting-undershoot/497092/2","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3569781,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-27T02:58:46.911Z","cooked":"

There are three values involved here:

  1. How far you command the robot to go.
  2. How far the robot measures it has gone.
  3. How far the robot moved in real life.

The most common error in pathplanning is error between 2 and 3, because your wheel size is inaccurate, or your wheels slip a little on the carpet. Changing P only effects the error between 1 and 2.

If you try to correct the error between 1 and 3 without determining whether the problem is with 1->2 or 2->3, you will struggle. It’s not clear to me from your post which error you are talking about when you say your robot ends “6 inches short”.

What you want to do is compare the distance the robot moved in real life to the distance measured by your encoder (not the path distance!), and scale your wheel diameter by a corresponding factor. One thing I would like us to try for our next comp is measure our wheel diameter when we run the test, and use that to provide adjustments as our tread wears through the event.

To tune P, look targetPose versus actualPose (which is number 2 above) in advantage scope (Pathplanner should automatically publish these over network tables).

bathtubed:

I believe PathPlanner has a somewhat large tolerance for reaching the end of a path, at which point it stops the PID controller.

Last time I looked at the code, which was last year, pathplanner was purely time based (i.e. it follows the path for a fixed time period, no matter how close it ends to the target).

Max_Morehead:
bathtubed:

I believe PathPlanner has a somewhat large tolerance for reaching the end of a path, at which point it stops the PID controller.

Last time I looked at the code, which was last year, pathplanner was purely time based (i.e. it follows the path for a fixed time period, no matter how close it ends to the target).

Ah, you’re right actually these are separate issues.
The dynamic path finding command has the large tolerance on the supplied pose.

The normal path follower command is just checking total time.
